overview: This subject is delivered every two years offering a study abroad experience taught intensively on location either in Prague at the Prague Quadrennial of Performance Design and Space or in the international location of World Stage Design held in a different city each festival.
These events are run two years apart from each other and are the most significant international festivals focusing on design and production for live performance.

Students participate in events showcasing current practice and emerging trends in the field including exhibitions, workshops, keynote lectures, discussions and performances to gain a deep and diverse insight into design and production for performance on the highest international level.

In this subject, students will engage in an intensive study abroad experience and costs in addition to tuition fees may be incurred. Students may be eligible for financial assistance, or the Overseas Help Loan (OS-HELP Loans).
ilo: engage with workshops, discussions, lectures and exhibitions in a thoughtful and organised manner;
articulate selected aspects of current practice in design or production for live performance in one or more international locations;
articulate own artistic position/place as a designer, technician or stage manager in the global context.

Prerequisites.content: Admission into the B-FAPRO Bachelor of Fine Arts (Production)
CodeNameTeaching periodCredit PointsDPSS10010Production Studio 2Semester 2 (On Campus - Southbank)25
Admission into the Performance Design major in the B-DES Bachelor of Design
Note: the following subject/s can also be taken concurrently (at the same time)

assessment.brief: Visual and written journal documenting activities undertaken
assessment.timing: 1 week after the end of intensive

assessment.brief: Reflective paper based on experience abroad
assessment.timing: 2 weeks after the end of intensive

assessment.brief: 8-minute oral presentation on one aspect of the international design festival.

assessment.hurdle: A minimum 75% punctual and full attendance is expected at all sessions. Students must complete all assessment requirements to be eligible to pass this subject.
